**This is a standing room performance. If you require accessiblity accommodations, please email boxoffice@nationalsawdust.org.**
* * *
Her last solo album, the critically-lauded _Head of Roses_ , took on heartbreak from a dualistic perspective, following a winding thread of intuition into the unknown and into healing. Her new album, _The Life You Save_ , takes that a step further; put simply, it‚Äôs the most honest, intimate and personally revealing record of Wasner‚Äôs career. As heart-wrenching as they are hopeful, its twelve tracks delve the depths of addiction and codependency, inherited and experienced trauma, and the process of finding peace in the face of others‚Äô suffering. _The Life You Save_ is resonant, unflinchingly exposed ‚Äì like a missive from the eye of a storm. But while it somehow manages to feel both viscerally raw and vulnerable, above it floats a sense of quiet peace, a sheen of hindsight, or perhaps of acceptance. It is the story of how it feels to be trapped between two worlds‚Äîthe one you came from, and the one you‚Äôve escaped to; about the belief that somehow, you can take the ones you love with you to this place; about the grief of realizing that the only person you can save is yourself.
‚Äç _The Life You Save_ was produced by Jenn Wasner and recorded at Betty‚Äôs in Chapel Hill, NC, and Montrose Recording in Los Angeles, CA, and includes the highlights ‚ÄúLong After Midnight,‚Äù ‚ÄúDefeat,‚Äù ‚ÄúAfraid,‚Äù ‚ÄúKeep Me In The Dark,‚Äù and ‚ÄúRiver In My Arms.‚Äù _The Life You Save_ also features additional production from Nick Sanborn (tracks 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 11), is engineered by Adrian Olsen & Alli Rogers, mixed by Adrian Olsen, and mastered by Huntley Miller.
Jenn writes on _‚Äç_** _The Life You Save_** _was produced by Jenn Wasner and recorded at Betty‚Äôs in Chapel Hill, NC, and Montrose Recording in Los Angeles, CA, and includes the highlights ‚ÄúLong After Midnight,‚Äù ‚ÄúDefeat,‚Äù ‚ÄúAfraid,‚Äù ‚ÄúKeep Me In The Dark,‚Äù and ‚ÄúRiver In My Arms.‚Äù_** _The Life You Save_** _also features additional production from Nick Sanborn (tracks 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 11), is engineered by Adrian Olsen & Alli Rogers, mixed by Adrian Olsen, and mastered by Huntley Miller._:
‚ÄúMy previous records, generally, have been a summary of things I had already been through‚Äî experiences I had observed and reflected upon, reporting back from some amount of distance. But this record is different. It is an attempt to report from inside of a process that is ongoing and unfinished, from which I will likely never fully emerge as long as I am alive: my struggle within the cycles of addiction and co-dependency.   

‚ÄúI set out trying to make a record about _other_ people.  

_‚ÄúTheir_ problems,_their_ struggles, _their_ addictions.  

‚ÄúI struggled for many years to give myself permission to write about this subject‚Äìworried that I was telling someone else‚Äôs story, a story that was not mine to tell. The work felt hazy and obscured; I was confused, and I struggled. The beauty of songwriting, at its best, is that it puts you in touch with your subconscious‚Äìa place where you can only tell the truth. Many of those truths were hard to accept. Some I don‚Äôt, even now, feel fully ready to say. But through this process, I came to understand that I was struggling with this record because I wasn‚Äôt being honest with myself. I was so deeply entrenched in the system in which I was raised that I thought I was outside of it, and the ways in which I continued to participate remained invisible to me.  

‚ÄúBut slowly, painstakingly, through this work I began to realize‚ÄîI am not _apart_ from all of this. I have been performing my role from a distance, but I am still engaged, still connected:  

_‚ÄúI‚Äôm inside it, after all._
‚ÄúAs it turns out, this record is not someone else‚Äôs story‚Äìit is mine, the story of my life. A life spent believing I had escaped, and that I deserved to feel guilty for doing so. A life in which I believed that the right combination of words, actions, effort, and expense could somehow change others‚Äô behavior. And a life in which blindness to my own patterns caused me to hurt others, and prevented me from finding the true love and acceptance I yearned for.   

‚ÄúThe belief that you can rescue others comes from more than one place, internally speaking. The part that is easiest to see and acknowledge is the one that stems from love, good intentions, and a genuine desire to offer care and support. But there‚Äôs an uglier side, and that part is harder to look at‚Äîthe ego, the pridefulness, the belief that you are better, stronger, somehow more deserving than all the rest. That through your attempts to control others‚Äô behavior, you can somehow secure a sense of safety for yourself.   

_‚ÄúI know the rules, but I ignore them,_
_I think I‚Äôm good enough to pull this off._  

‚ÄúOr, more simply:   

_‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm god; I know I‚Äôm not._  

‚ÄúFor me, that was the puzzle piece that finally made it all make sense. But it was also the piece that was the hardest to hold. It took a long time for me to build up enough love‚Äînot for others, but for myself‚Äîthat acknowledging this truth would not break me. I understand now that I‚Äôm not the savior, not the hero, not the chosen one. I‚Äôm spinning in my own wheel, a bundle of addictions and adaptations and blind spots, just like everybody else. And there is a beauty to that, along with a kind of freedom.   

In the end, it is my hope that this record exists as a testament to the depth of my love for those I cannot save, and that it might provide some comfort for anyone who is still learning how to love and live for themselves.
‚Äç
‚Äç**ABOUT NATALIE JANE HILL**
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/5ea4ada849d1a708b00fb8b1/68b848b21523228bc1d54243_NJH%20.jpeg)
Natalie Jane Hill is a Texas native guitarist and singer-songwriter currently based in the mountains of North Carolina. She writes songs that reach for the haunted and comforting corners of the natural world, dressed in a gently virtuosic and singular approach to finger-style guitar.

# Bolden.
[](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/bolden#redesign)
[Performances](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/performances-prev)[HOME](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/bolden#home)[IDEAS](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/bolden)
BOLDEN. is a fast-rising jazz house duo blending the soul of jazz with the rhythm of electronic music. Emerging from the UK‚Äôs vibrant underground scene, Reuben Barrett and Catherine Rannus, both gifted multi-instrumentalists with contrasting but complementary musical journeys, are forging a new path for modern jazz and electronic fusion. 
LIVE AT NATIONAL SAWDUST // DOORS AT 6:30PM
November 12, 2025
7:30 pm
[BUY TICKETS](https://ci.ovationtix.com/36490/production/1248167)
This event has passed
![facebook sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/facebook.svg)
![twitter sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/twitter.svg)
![pinterest sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/pinterest.svg)

## What‚Äôs a Rich Text element?
The rich text element allows you to create and format headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, images, and video all in one place instead of having to add and format them individually. Just double-click and easily create content.
#### Static and dynamic content editing
A rich text element can be used with static or dynamic content. For static content, just drop it into any page and begin editing. For dynamic content, add a rich text field to any collection and then connect a rich text element to that field in the settings panel. [Voila!](http://google.com)
#### How to customize formatting for each rich text

Reuben, a self-taught artist of guitar, bass, drums and keyboard, brings a raw, intuitive approach to rhythm and harmony. Catherine, a classically trained pianist, vocalist, and multi-instrumentalist on flute and saxophone, brings a strong sense of melody, harmony, and feel to BOLDEN.‚Äôs evolving sound. As one of the few women in the modern jazz house space, especially on the instrumental side, Catherine brings a vital and often underrepresented perspective to the genre. Her presence on stage and in the studio not only redefines expectations but also opens space for a more inclusive vision of what jazz music can be.
While Reuben first started BOLDEN. in November 2023, Reuben and Catherine first connected in August 2024 through a shared musical vision. What began as a one-off collaboration quickly evolved into a dynamic artistic partnership. 
The name **BOLDEN.** is a tribute to Charles ‚ÄúBuddy‚Äù Bolden, the early jazz cornetist whose improvisational spirit laid the foundation for an entire genre. _‚ÄúIt felt right to name the project after someone who helped birth jazz,‚Äù_ they shared. _‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not trying to recreate what jazz was, we‚Äôre continuing its story.‚Äù_ That story now includes their own contributions: a fast-growing catalogue of tracks that channel the expressiveness of jazz, the pulse of house music, and the freedom of live performance.
* * *
**This is a standing room-only performance. If you require accessibility accommodations, please email boxoffice@nationalsawdust.org.**
Live, BOLDEN. is magnetic. Their live set features Reuben and Catherine jumping between saxophone, flute, drums, bass, guitar, keys and vocals, improvising harmonies and pushing arrangements in the moment. Each show feels one-of-a-kind, designed to evolve in real time.
In a short period of time, BOLDEN. has rapidly gained momentum, amassing millions of streams and earning over **_a million monthly_ **listeners on Spotify, landing placements on major editorial playlists including **New Music Friday UK** , **Jazz UK, Jazz House** and more.**Jazz House Lounge,** into a thriving community of over **_50,000 listeners_** , making it one of the largest fan-driven playlists created by a jazz artist today. While selling out their debut shows in York and at London‚Äôs OMEARA, BOLDEN. is quickly becoming one of the most talked-about new acts in live music.
Their upcoming EP, **‚Äò _Would appear to be jazz.‚Äô_** , pushes their vision further, both musically and conceptually. Named after a line from Catherine‚Äôs university dissertation on gender inequality in the music industry, the project challenges narrow definitions of jazz while spotlighting the genre‚Äôs often-overlooked barriers. Across its tracks, BOLDEN. blends live jazz performance with house, all while questioning who gets to define what jazz is and who gets to participate in it. It‚Äôs bold, groove-driven, and purposefully provocative.

Hannah Frances (b. 1997) is a vocalist, guitarist, composer, and poet that NPR‚Äôs Ann Powers calls ‚Äúa stunning vocalist and songwriter, making monumental and mythic freak folk,‚Äù and was awarded Pitchfork‚Äôs Best New Music for her triumphant new album Keeper of the Shepherd. Through cutting lyricism and astute fingerpicked polyrhythms, Frances‚Äô perennial sound melds avant-folk, progressive rock, and jazz.

BlackBox Ensemble performs the U.S. premiere of PIPA BOY: Three Scenes from the Post-Diaspora by Baldwin Giang, a multimedia work for ensemble and pipa player exploring global identity and the conditions of belonging and non-belonging. The video part features collaborations with three international filmmakers. The program also includes work by Anthony Cheung, Misato Mochizuki, and Giang's song cycle butterfly, posthumously.

## What‚Äôs a Rich Text element?
The rich text element allows you to create and format headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, images, and video all in one place instead of having to add and format them individually. Just double-click and easily create content.

**/// This program is Co-Presented by American Academy in Rome.**
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/5ea4ada849d1a708b00fb8b1/689211c6b0c58e0924ec5f84_Serif%20Logo%20Orange%20No%20Background%20\(1\).png)
**ABOUT BALDWIN GIANG**
Baldwin Giang is a Seattle-based composer and multi-instrumentalist, and winner of the Samuel Barber Rome Prize from the American Academy in Rome. He was composer-in-residence with the Louisville Orchestra from 2024-2025. His music has been performed at Carnegie Hall, Symphony Center in Chicago, and the Smithsonian Museum in DC. International festivals that have presented his work include IRCAM‚Äôs Manifeste (FR), Gaudeamus Muziekweek (NL), Spoleto Festival dei Due Mondi (IT), Ostrava Days (CZ), and Aspen Music Festival. Commissioners and collaborators have included New Jersey Symphony, Albany Symphony, Civic Orchestra of Chicago, New York Youth Symphony, Ensemble Intercontemporain, Riot Ensemble, International Contemporary Ensemble, and Tanglewood Music Festival.
Baldwin is a graduate of Yale University and the University of Michigan. He won a Charles Ives Scholarship from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Prix Ravel, ASCAP‚Äôs Morton Gould and Leo Kaplan Awards, Fulbright fellowship to Taiwan, Gaudeamus Prize nomination, and Yale‚Äôs Beekman Cannon Friends and Abraham Beekman Cox Prizes. He resides in Seattle and serves as Assistant Professor of Composition at Pacific Lutheran University.
‚Äç
**ABOUT BLACKBOX ENSEMBLE**
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/5ea4ada849d1a708b00fb8b1/68a3381f9f32119787567320_IMG_1661%202.jpg)
BlackBox Ensemble is a New York-based collective of contemporary performers reshaping the boundaries of new music. We treat sound as a living, porous medium shaped by genre-defiance, interdisciplinary dialogue, and the urgency of the present moment. We believe that music, as a cultural medium, fills the role of the ‚Äúblack box,‚Äù enacting an ambiguous but vital relationship between artistic expression and social life. In doing so, we strive to follow the inspiration of the theatrical definition‚Äîto cultivate connection among artists and audiences, and to foster innovation as a creative laboratory for adaptable experimentation.
Founded in 2018, our wide-ranging projects have brought us from major concert halls to museum galleries, the mountainous landscape of the Berkshires, the woods of Michigan, the Hudson River waterfront, and an underground karaoke bar in midtown Manhattan. Our 2024-2025 season has consisted of concerts in New York and around the country, including the season-opening performance of the Southern Exposure Series at the University of South Carolina, a residency at the University of Chicago Center for Contemporary Composition, performances Julius Eastman‚Äôs _Femenine_ with the Kyle Marshall Choreography Company at PS 21 in Chatham, NY, and performances on Bang on a Can‚Äôs _Long Play_ Festival and the Whitney Museum‚Äôs Decade Downtown celebration. Past projects include a site-responsive, outdoor music and dance performance at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Massachusetts, the staged premiere of Borrowed Landscape, a radio play by German playwright duo tauchgold with music by Dai Fujikura, at the Noguchi Museum and Smithsonian Museum of Asian Art, and our inaugural BlackBox Festival, in celebration of our 5th anniversary, which featured multiple world and NYC premieres and included our debut at NYC‚Äôs historic Roulette Intermedium.

‚ÄúNo harpist thus far has been more capable of combining all of the modern harp traditions ‚Äî from Salzedo, through Dorothy Ashby, through Alice Coltrane ‚Äî with such strength, grace and commitment.‚Äù - The New York Times

## What‚Äôs a Rich Text element?
The rich text element allows you to create and format headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, images, and video all in one place instead of having to add and format them individually. Just double-click and easily create content.
#### Static and dynamic content editing
A rich text element can be used with static or dynamic content. For static content, just drop it into any page and begin editing. For dynamic content, add a rich text field to any collection and then connect a rich text element to that field in the settings panel. [Voila!](http://google.com)

Brandee Younger is revolutionizing the harps‚Äô role in modern music. Over the past fifteen years, she has worked relentlessly to stretch boundaries and limitations for harpists. In 2022, she made history by becoming the first Black woman to be nominated for a Grammy¬Æ Award for Best Instrumental Composition. That same year, she was also nominated for an NAACP Image Award and later, the winner of the 2024 NAACP Image Award in the category of Outstanding Jazz Album for her latest album Brand New Life. Ever-expanding as an artist, she has worked with cultural icons including Common, Lauryn Hill, John Legend, Pharoah Sanders and Christian McBride. Her original composition ‚ÄúHortense‚Äù was featured in the Netflix Concert-Documentary, Beyonc√©: Homecoming and in 2019, Brandee was selected to perform her original music as a featured performer for Quincy Jones and Steve McQueens‚Äô ‚ÄúSoundtrack of America‚Äù. Brandee is often noted for standing on the shoulders of the very women who ushered in the harp as a clear and distinct voice in jazz & popular styles -  
particularly Detroit natives Dorothy Ashby & Alice Coltrane. Her latest album, Brand New Life, builds on her already rich oeuvre, and cements the harp‚Äôs place in popular culture. As the title of the album suggests, Brand New Life is about forging new paths‚Äìartistic, personal, political, and spiritual. Younger's music is imbued with a sense of purpose and respect of legacy, creating a larger platform for the harp to reach newer and wider audiences than ever before. In addition to performing and recording, Brandee Younger is on the faculty at New York University, Steinhardt School and The New School College of Performing Arts. Follow: @harpista

# Madame Gandhi
[](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/madame-gandhi-3-20-26#redesign)
[Performances](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/performances-prev)[HOME](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/madame-gandhi-3-20-26#home)[IDEAS](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/madame-gandhi-3-20-26)
‚ÄúThe hyphen-rich vocalist-percussionist-speaker-producer-activist‚Äôs vibe isn‚Äôt so much ‚Äúsinger-songwriter‚Äù as ‚Äúicon of empowerment.‚Äù Her frenetic odes to feminism, fluidity and freedom ‚Äî carried off with the assistance of an entirely female or nonbinary band ‚Äî mash together fragments of electro-pop, trap, Afrobeat and R&B, carried off with endless swagger.‚Äù ‚Äì NPR
LIVE AT NATIONAL SAWDUST // DOORS AT 6:30PM
March 20, 2026
7:30 pm
[BUY TICKETS](https://ci.ovationtix.com/36490/production/1234690)

## What‚Äôs a Rich Text element?
The rich text element allows you to create and format headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, images, and video all in one place instead of having to add and format them individually. Just double-click and easily create content.
#### Static and dynamic content editing
A rich text element can be used with static or dynamic content. For static content, just drop it into any page and begin editing. For dynamic content, add a rich text field to any collection and then connect a rich text element to that field in the settings panel. [Voila!](http://google.com)
#### How to customize formatting for each rich text
Headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, figures, images, and figure captions can all be styled after a class is added to the rich text element using the "When inside of" nested selector system.
**This is a standing room-only performance. If you require ADA accommodations, please email boxoffice@nationalsawdust.org.**
* * *
The last time we heard from Madame Gandhi was via her effervescent, self-reflective album Vibrations (Sony Masterworks, 2022). She had emerged from the pandemic, having spent time in homebound introspection, even earning a master‚Äôs degree in Music, Science, and Technology from Stanford University.
In contrast, for her follow-up, the rhythmic, eclectic, contact-high of Let Me Be Water (We Make Noise, May 2025), she quite literally traveled to the ends of the world ‚Äî the Arctic Circle and Antarctica. There, she recorded the sounds of glaciers melting with hydrophones she had built at Stanford‚Äôs Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve drawn a lot of inspiration from nature,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúThis is about realizing that we are nature.‚Äù
Kiran ‚ÄúMadame‚Äù Gandhi ‚Äî who began as a percussionist for M.I.A, before exploding into a genre-defying musical artist ‚Äî has navigated many paths to get to this place of peace. A decade ago, her free-bleeding London Marathon run went viral, challenging stigmas around menstruation. Five years later, she delivered a mainstage TED Talk (‚ÄúWhy We Must Stop Dancing to the Sound of Our Own Oppression‚Äù) which elucidated her music-activism and gained millions of views online. Shortly after, the video for her song ‚ÄúWaiting For Me‚Äù won a Jury Award at SXSW 2021. In between, she toured with Daybreaker opening Oprah‚Äôs stadium tour, and her music was featured on Gutsy, Hillary Clinton‚Äôs AppleTV+ series, and Netflix‚Äôs Never Have I Ever. Recently, she received the Songwriter‚Äôs Hall of Fame Abe Olman Prize and was elected governor of her local Grammy chapter, championing unsung talent. Looking back, it‚Äôs clear Kiran has incrementally lived up to her name, which means ‚Äúray of light‚Äù in Sanskrit.
Inspiration is a living, breathing, evolving entity for this cultural force who resides between Los Angeles and London. Let Me Be Water, in kind, represents an artistic transformation for her: The album is an appreciation of the grandeur of nature, but also our collective role in this greater force. ‚ÄúIt is about flow,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt is about acceptance. It is about existing without pushback.‚Äù And that is how Let Me Be Water became the ultimate act of collaboration: Though co-produced and performed by Gandhi, it was actually composed by 40 women and gender-expansive creatives.
Its opener, the percolating ‚ÄúLet Me Be Water,‚Äù is a deceivingly effortless track that mingles spoken-word samples and mantra-like house vocals with the aforementioned audio of melting glaciers. (Gandhi is no stranger to this aesthetic, having recorded ‚ÄúIn Purpose,‚Äù a track composed of natural sounds, for EarthPercent, a charity co-founded by Brian Eno to raise funds for environmental causes.) ‚ÄúThe song is absolutely a reference to climate, to protecting the planet,‚Äù she explains. ‚Äú‚ÄòLet me be water‚Äô ‚Äî let‚Äôs identify that we are all one with nature.‚Äù 
The idea of unifying several musical perspectives into one album came to her after leading a pair of songwriting camps with We Make Noise, an organization and label founded by Erin Barra that‚Äôs devoted to gender equity in music. Barra invited Gandhi to mentor the teams of artists first in 2023 at The Music District in Colorado, then several months later at Arizona State University. (Alicia Key‚Äôs women-in-music organization She Is the Music as well as the nonprofit Salt Lick Incubator helped fund the effort.) Gandhi was asked to record only the winning song, she says, ‚ÄúBut after the vibe, camaraderie, and positive energy of the experience, I decided to honor the efforts of all 10 teams and make it into a 10-song album.‚Äù She tapped Colby Lapolla from the camp to co-produce the album with her and further develop the songs.
Inclusiveness drove the We Make Noise sessions: Be electric and percussive, while being uplifting and thoughtful, prioritizing lyrics with consciousness. The resulting music not only reflects these women galvanizing, but also a desire to transmit that energy to whomever is listening. For instance, the winning song, the worldly anthem ‚ÄúRise!‚Äù is a self-affirmation that doubles as a call to action. Meanwhile, the pop single ‚ÄúTake Your Time!‚Äù captures the ethos of introspection and manifestation that comes from taking those bold steps. In 2018, a USC report found that only 2% of producers are women, which means it is likely that an even smaller percentage identify as trans or gender non-conforming. This album serves as a direct response to combating this underwhelming statistic.
To set intentions each morning, Gandhi would lead the 40 songwriters in meditation, journaling, and gentle yoga movement. ‚ÄúIt was experimental and cool,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe looked at themes around using your purpose and passion to make a difference in the world. We looked at what it means to be aware of others, and how does that play out?‚Äù Let Me Be Water clocks in at a little over 20 minutes, the same amount of time she spends each morning meditating. ‚ÄúYou can dance, you can celebrate, you can work out, you can get your day going,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt is made with the intention of making the audience feel uplifted and empowered, and to celebrate the spirit of love.‚Äù
A part of Let Me Be Water was inspired by Gandhi‚Äôs romantic partner, Team GB gold-medalist boxer Lesley Sackey, whom she unofficially married at Burning Man in 2023. Sackey teaches boxing to domestic violence survivors as a type of therapy and encouraged Gandhi to step into the ring for the first time, too. For three months, Gandhi trained with a team of 10 women under Sackey‚Äôs coaching, and went on to win a fight in London in 2024. The experience was so transformative that the album‚Äôs first single is the paean to the sport: ‚ÄúPisces Knockout‚Äù is an agile, auto-tuned track produced by Colby Lapolla paced to a steady flow of power-hook shots and Indian Sarangi. ‚ÄúThe song is about unmasking, about fighting the powers that keep us eating poorly and consuming harmful substances,‚Äù says Gandhi, who also became vegan and stopped drinking alcohol in recent years, ‚Äúadvertising and marketing that keep us addicted to many different things.‚Äù
She found boxing to be an expression of ‚Äúpersonal power and strength, stamina and commitment.‚Äù To that end, the set of photographs (shot by Lindsey Byrnes) for Let Me Be Water is inspired by the famous Life magazine photos of Muhammad Ali training underwater. She hopes the steadied liberation woven throughout Let Me Be Water will prove contagious. ‚ÄúI do feel very much like a butterfly out of the cocoon on the other side. I feel more in my power energy,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd when we show up for ourselves, it ends up being medicine for others.‚Äù

# contemplations
## Contemplations is a celebration of National Sawdust's work from inception through the 6th season in 2020-21, and a tribute to all the artists, collaborators, funders, and friends who have made it possible. A special thanks to the National Sawdust board and team who collectively help us make our dreams into reality.
## This book features the photographic work of Jill Steinberg, with curation and story by Paola Prestini. It is a companion project to the television and video broadcast series of the same name developed in partnership with The WNET Group's ALL ARTS platforms featuring highlights of National Sawdust's work in the world.
## [Learn more about Contemplations here.](https://ci.ovationtix.com/36490/store/products/83395)

extraction.title: ShiShi (Live) - Indigo Tour
extraction.description: Join ShiShi for a one-night-only presentation of his latest album 'Indigo,' blending rock, electronic and devotional music to tell a story of deep spiritual longing.

[ Nina Keith and Rachika Nayar were drawn to one another like mirror images or two sisters reuniting after a lifetime of separation. Four years ago, the artists met in Brooklyn's two-block‚Äìby‚Äìtwo-block Maria Hernandez Park after fan-girling each other‚Äôs music online. Dishing about messy post-lockdown long-distance lesbianism, heartfelt investments in Buddhist and Hindu philosophies, and a shared high-school love of the Eternal Sunshine OST, the two found their surface similarities gesturing toward a deeper shared existential worldview. Presented in partnership with AdHoc. September 12, 2025 - Rachika Nayar and Nina Keith Present Disiniblud This is some text inside of a div block. [ When guitarist and composer Yasmin Williams sits down to compose music, she doesn‚Äôt scour her subconscious for unheard melodies or clever chord progressions. Instead, she goes granular‚Äîfixating on a single note. She‚Äôll play it over and over, sustaining it, varying the attack or the release to change its essence, eventually adding notes to form chords. In addition to the crisp fingerpicked guitar that helped establish her as a fast-rising star of instrumental folk, Williams plays kora, harp guitar, banjo, and electric guitar and bass‚Äîall with authority. September 20, 2025 - Yasmin Williams + Special Guests This is some text inside of a div block. [ After spending the majority of his adult life thus far in New York, Juan Wauters decides to revisit his native Montevideo, the culturally rich capital of Uruguay. Wauters explored the excitement of falling back in love with his birthplace on his subsequent record, 2023‚Äôs Wandering Rebel, but on his seventh studio album MVD LUV ‚Äî due June 27 via Captured Tracks ‚Äî Wauters doesn‚Äôt just introduce listeners to Montevideo; he invites them to feel at home within it. Having spent much of his career in the United States, Wauters has long carried the dual identity of immigrant and native son. With MVD LUV, a love letter to both his roots and his present, he set out to bridge those worlds by capturing the essence of Montevideo‚Äôs streets and communal spirit. September 26, 2025 - Juan Wauters This is some text inside of a div block. This is some text inside of a div block. ](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/juan-wauters)
[ Zola Jesus aka Nika is an American born singer, songwriter and producer. Since 2008, she has released two EPs and seven (?) full-length albums majoratively on NY multi-decade tastemaker label Sacred Bones. Nika began training as an opera singer at the age of 10. She dismantled that training to deliver her breakthrough lo-fi record The Spoils in 2009, most of which she recorded as an undergrad in her dorm room at UW Madison. [ For the longing listener‚Ä¶ The music of composer Dan English is the communing of the head and the heart sharing secrets. Across the last few decades ‚Äì whether it be as Flock of Dimes, as half of beloved duo Wye Oak, or via one of her many collaborations with Bon Iver, Sylvan Esso, and a sprawling list of other musical juggernauts ‚Äì Wasner‚Äôs extensive catalog displays her gift for balancing authenticity and directness with an unmistakable left-of-center sensibility. # contemplations
## Contemplations is a celebration of National Sawdust's work from inception through the 6th season in 2020-21, and a tribute to all the artists, collaborators, funders, and friends who have made it possible. A special thanks to the National Sawdust board and team who collectively help us make our dreams into reality.
## This book features the photographic work of Jill Steinberg, with curation and story by Paola Prestini. It is a companion project to the television and video broadcast series of the same name developed in partnership with The WNET Group's ALL ARTS platforms featuring highlights of National Sawdust's work in the world.
## [Learn more about Contemplations here.](https://ci.ovationtix.com/36490/store/products/83395)

# Rachika Nayar and Nina Keith Present Disiniblud
[](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/rachika-nayar-and-nina-keith-present-disiniblud#redesign)
[Performances](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/performances-prev)[HOME](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/rachika-nayar-and-nina-keith-present-disiniblud#home)[IDEAS](https://www.nationalsawdust.org/event/rachika-nayar-and-nina-keith-present-disiniblud)
Nina Keith and Rachika Nayar were drawn to one another like mirror images or two sisters reuniting after a lifetime of separation. Four years ago, the artists met in Brooklyn's two-block‚Äìby‚Äìtwo-block Maria Hernandez Park after fan-girling each other‚Äôs music online. Dishing about messy post-lockdown long-distance lesbianism, heartfelt investments in Buddhist and Hindu philosophies, and a shared high-school love of the Eternal Sunshine OST, the two found their surface similarities gesturing toward a deeper shared existential worldview. Presented in partnership with AdHoc.
LIVE AT NATIONAL SAWDUST // DOORS AT 6:30PM
September 12, 2025
7:30 pm
[BUY TICKETS](https://ci.ovationtix.com/36490/production/1240898)
This event has passed
![facebook sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/facebook.svg)
![twitter sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/twitter.svg)
![pinterest sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/pinterest.svg)
![sharethis sharing button](https://platform-cdn.sharethis.com/img/sharethis.svg)
## What‚Äôs a Rich Text element?
The rich text element allows you to create and format headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, images, and video all in one place instead of having to add and format them individually. Just double-click and easily create content.
#### Static and dynamic content editing
A rich text element can be used with static or dynamic content. For static content, just drop it into any page and begin editing. For dynamic content, add a rich text field to any collection and then connect a rich text element to that field in the settings panel. [Voila!](http://google.com)
#### How to customize formatting for each rich text
Headings, paragraphs, blockquotes, figures, images, and figure captions can all be styled after a class is added to the rich text element using the "When inside of" nested selector system.
**This is a standing room-only performance. If you require accessibility accommodations, please email**[**boxoffice@nationalsawdust.org**](http://boxoffice@nationalsawdust.org)**.**
* * *
Their kinship‚Äîwhich Rachika describes originating from some ‚Äúinner-child sisterhood place‚Äù‚Äîis the heart of their collaborative project Disiniblud and their fairytale-like self-titled LP via Smugglers Way. The two‚Äôs self-described ‚Äúwordless conversation,‚Äù the album orbits such themes as mortality, reinvention through destruction, and sublimating fractured histories into music‚Äîall resulting in a work that suggests sweeping transformation can come from embracing old wounds with childlike wonder.
The two LA-based artists meet on complementary but seemingly disparate musical grounds. On her 2022 breakout LP _Heaven Come Crashing_ , Nayar departed from her usual ambient guitar in favor of maximalist synths, sub-bass, and flickers of Amen breaks. Her distinct fusion of post-rock and electronica earned her accolades as Pitchfork's Best New Music, on several best of the year lists (The New York Times, Stereogum, Fader, GQ, Bandcamp, etc), and as the opening act on tour with M83. Keith, meanwhile, is best known for her self-trained approach to composition, as evident on her 2019 debut _MARANASATI 19111_ and its delicate medley of cello, piano, clarinet, and flute, used to explore a personal history marked by community tragedy and paranormal incidents. She expands into new territories on her forthcoming releases, like the single ‚ÄúCome Back Different‚Äù featuring Julie Byrne, by incorporating modular synths and intricate vocal arrangements with the help of various collaborators. Their combined artistic strengths exalt together on _Disiniblud_.
"The imagery [of the album] for me is like standing together in the abyss of our memory and reckoning with both the ineffable wonders and atrocities of our life experience," says Nina, "like we‚Äôre holding and protecting each other through that process and finding a way to take both the light and dark.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about healing and moving past the darkness,‚Äù clarifies Rachika.
Nina adds, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs taking both with you in the satchel and carrying it with you everywhere you go‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs the only way you can really metabolize it.‚Äù
This protection Nina refers to can be as uplifting as encouraging one another to re-enliven a part of their musical repertoire‚Äîfor Rachika, it might be math-rock guitar abilities at which she shrugs that Nina insists on coaxing out of her; for Nina, it could be her vast hard drive of abandoned modular synth sketches that Rachika inspires her to put to use again (at the climax of the track "Serpentine" featuring Cassandra Croft, for instance). Nina describes this in metaphor like showing off an outfit she used to wear all the time three years ago that now feels outdated, but then "the other one of us sees the jewel there and brings it out." Sometimes, protecting each other through the process can also be, Rachika explains, "us both arriving at the studio in tears, holding each other for 10 minutes‚Ä¶ but instead of picking apart whatever struggles with words, we'll just start playing‚Äîand then a door opens for both of us."
Though these two have such a strong intuitive connection, making music together was often unintentional. The first time Rachika visited Nina in LA before her own move, she handed Nina her suitcases and immediately sat down at Nina's new piano. Nina quickly set up microphones to record the moment of spontaneity without disturbing her, thus producing the song ‚ÄúNice rocks in my mouth‚Äù (unreleased), which they worked on for two days straight without so much as a concrete plan. "Serpentine" is another result of loose improvisation: Rachika absentmindedly playing guitar on Nina's bed while water dripping from Nina‚Äôs sound installation ‚ÄúPeriphone‚Äù audibly struck metallophone bars in the background. Out of a 72-minute long recording, they found a thirty second excerpt to loop behind Cassandra‚Äôs soaring soprano vocals.
This fluency and fluidity also intertwines with the way they'll experiment with new instruments and techniques under their mutual guidance and support. Nina refers to it as "cosplaying as each other." Rachika might try her hand learning the instruments in Nina‚Äôs studio (such as piano and clarinet), while Nina will experiment with bass put through Rachika's guitar pedals and unique methods of audio time-stretching.
"I think we encourage each other to do things outside the ‚Äòidentity‚Äô of our solo projects, especially musical abilities from our deep pasts we've put aside for feelings around gender or shame," Rachika says. "But it‚Äôs through the other‚Äôs eyes we get to bring it somewhere new."
Above all, their practice emphasizes comfort and trust before engaging in childlike play‚Äîa state of being that sheds bounded self-consciousness in favor of open imagination. Nina envisions this as she and Rachika's younger selves packing a satchel, holding hands, and daring one another to run away into a place of "wounds and wonder," only to discover an unforeseeable magic in an amalgam of post-rock, glitchy indie electronica, ambient, and pop genres in this co-created realm.
"Blue Rags, Raging Wind," the most neoclassical entry on the album and rife with xylophone-esque patters, exemplifies this core of "inner childlike joy," says Rachika. It was born one day out of a fun, uninhibited moment riffing out polyrhythms together on a sound installation in Nina's room. The title track "Disiniblud" also recalls "going into a three-year old mind" for the purposes of free exploration. Much of the song's mixed metallic percussion and whirring electronics came from banging on various kitchen supplies with a stick and then processing the recording into a major key anthem.
"I think there's something crucial about childhood and playfulness in my approach to life,‚Äù says Rachika, ‚Äúrediscovering what potential existed before the limits other people decided for you and finding out what queer things happen if you lean into those previously closed paths."
Rediscovering the past and excavating these "memory networks, all of these different fears and internalized structures on how to survive in the world" can be fruitful, says Nina, but even more than that, "something miraculous can happen when you burn it to the ground." Gaining and growing often involves the process of letting go, too, as expressed in the opener "Give-upping" featuring Julianna Barwick. Lush with buoyant piano melodies, Barwick's fluttering vocals beckon to the listener from the other side of an "infinite knowingness," says Rachika, to‚Äîas the lyrics instruct‚Äî"Give up/ Give up/ For once if you let it." The song taps into a longheld Buddhist truth of clinging to past experiences as a source of one's own suffering.
Rife with almost merry-go-round samples from three different vocalists (Katie Dey, Julianna, and Willy Siegel of Ponytail), "It's Change," is also a mantra of impermanence in its own right. "There is no ground beneath us," insists Nina. "You have this perfect life? It's already gone‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just dust. The structures you‚Äôve built in your life, everyone you know, will eventually pass, and that awareness allows you to see how precious it all is without clinging to this projected reality.‚Äù
All things go and this acknowledgement recognizes that, as Rachika describes, ‚Äúcatastrophe and freedom are twin realities bound together.‚Äù With that release and even intentional destruction, there comes a sense of peace in this larger story‚Äîa ‚Äúfairytale of two sisters ripping everything apart to find the jewel in each other.‚Äù
**ABOUT ELORI SAXL**
![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/5ea4ada849d1a708b00fb8b1/689cd18c33017be49be57e4c_01_Elori%20Saxl%20-%20Max%20Basch.jpg)
Elori Saxl is an American experimental electronic composer. Her debut album The Blue of Distance (released 2021 on Western Vinyl) received critical acclaim for its elegant combination of digitally-processed recordings of wind and water with the rich sounds of analog synthesizers and chamber orchestra. Half-written in the verdant Adirondack mountains of northern New York in a hot summer filled with love, ecstasy, and a feeling of promise, and half-written in the frozen Apostle Islands in Lake Superior in the dead of winter looking back at videos from the summer, The Blue of Distance effortlessly captures the gentle sorrows of nostalgia in an age of perpetual digital memory.
Saxl has composed music for classical ensembles, The Guggenheim, Burton, Patagonia, Google, Poler, Dove, the New Yorker, This American Life, Public Radio International, SFMOMA, and more. Her music has been featured by Pitchfork, The New Yorker, WNYC New Sounds, BBC 3 Radio, Popmatters, Dusted, A Closer Listen, and more. Her film work has been nominated for two Emmys and been featured by the New Yorker, Vimeo Staff Picks, and festivals around the world.
